@description.body:

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Single-value binding is a core component of the data binding package.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: internal reference for all bindings indexed by source object

@description.name: @description
@description.body: internal reference for all bindings indexed by target object

@description.name: @description
@description.body:
The function is responsible for binding a source objects property to a target objects property. Both properties have to have the usual qooxdoo getter and setter. The source property also needs to fire change-events on every change of its value. Please keep in mind, that this binding is unidirectional. If you need a binding in both directions, you have to use two of this bindings. It's also possible to bind some kind of a hierarchy as a source. This means that you can separate the source properties with a dot and bind by that the object referenced to this property chain. Example with an object 'a' which has object 'b' stored in its 'child' property. Object b has a string property named abc: 

qx.data.SingleValueBinding.bind(a, "child.abc", textfield, "value");
In that case, if the property abc of b changes, the textfield will automatically contain the new value. Also if the child of a changes, the new value (abc of the new child) will be in the textfield. There is also a possibility of binding an array. Therefore the array {@link qx.data.IListData} is needed because this array has change events which the native does not. Imagine a qooxdoo object a which has a children property containing an array holding more of its own kind. Every object has a name property as a string. 
var svb = qx.data.SingleValueBinding;
// bind the first child's name of 'a' to a textfield
svb.bind(a, "children[0].name", textfield, "value");
// bind the last child's name of 'a' to a textfield
svb.bind(a, "children[last].name", textfield2, "value");
// also deeper bindings are possible
svb.bind(a, "children[0].children[0].name", textfield3, "value");
As you can see in this example, the abc property of a's b will be bound to the textfield. If now the value of b changed or even the a will get a new b, the binding still shows the right value.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: sourceObject {qx.core.Object} The source of the binding.
@param.description: The source of the binding.

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
sourcePropertyChain {String} The property chain which represents
the source property.
@param.description:
The property chain which represents
the source property.

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
targetObject {qx.core.Object} The object which the source should
be bind to.
@param.description:
The object which the source should
be bind to.

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
targetPropertyChain {String} The property chain to the target
object.
@param.description:
The property chain to the target
object.

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
options {Map?null} A map containing the options.
  • converter: A converter function which takes four parameters and should return the converted value.
    1. The data to convert
    2. The corresponding model object, which is only set in case of the use of an controller.
    3. The source object for the binding
    4. The target object.
    If no conversion has been done, the given value should be returned. e.g. a number to boolean converter function(data, model, source, target) {return data > 100;}
  • onUpdate: A callback function can be given here. This method will be called if the binding was updated successful. There will be three parameter you do get in that method call.
    1. The source object
    2. The target object
    3. The data
    Here is a sample: onUpdate : function(source, target, data) {...}
  • onSetFail: A callback function can be given here. This method will be called if the set of the value fails.
  • ignoreConverter: A string which will be matched using the current property chain. If it matches, the converter will not be called.
@param.description:
A map containing the options.
  • converter: A converter function which takes four parameters and should return the converted value.
    1. The data to convert
    2. The corresponding model object, which is only set in case of the use of an controller.
    3. The source object for the binding
    4. The target object.
    If no conversion has been done, the given value should be returned. e.g. a number to boolean converter function(data, model, source, target) {return data > 100;}
  • onUpdate: A callback function can be given here. This method will be called if the binding was updated successful. There will be three parameter you do get in that method call.
    1. The source object
    2. The target object
    3. The data
    Here is a sample: onUpdate : function(source, target, data) {...}
  • onSetFail: A callback function can be given here. This method will be called if the set of the value fails.
  • ignoreConverter: A string which will be matched using the current property chain. If it matches, the converter will not be called.

@return.name: @return
@return.body:
{var} Returns the internal id for that binding. This can be used
for referencing the binding or e.g. for removing. This is not an atomic
id so you can't you use it as a hash-map index.
@return.description:
Returns the internal id for that binding. This can be used
for referencing the binding or e.g. for removing. This is not an atomic
id so you can't you use it as a hash-map index.

target).

there is no property definition for object and property (source and
target).

@description.name: @description
@description.body:
Tries to return a fitting event name to the given source object and
property name. First, it assumes that the property name is a real property
and therefore it checks the property definition for the event. The second
possibility is to check if there is an event with the given name. The
third and last possibility checked is if there is an event which is named
change + propertyName. If this three possibilities fail, an error will be
thrown.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: source {qx.core.Object} The source where the property is stored.
@param.description: The source where the property is stored.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: propertyName {String} The name of the property.
@param.description: The name of the property.

@return.name: @return
@return.body: {String|null} The name of the corresponding event or null.
@return.description: The name of the corresponding event or null.

@description.name: @description
@description.body:
Internal helper method which is actually doing all bindings. That means
that an event listener will be added to the source object which listens
to the given event and invokes an set on the target property on the
targetObject.
This method does not store the binding in the internal reference store
so it should NOT be used from outside this class. For an outside usage,
use {@link #bind}.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: sourceObject {qx.core.Object} The source of the binding.
@param.description: The source of the binding.

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
sourceEvent {String} The event of the source object which could
be the change event in common but has to be an
{@link qx.event.type.Data} event.
@param.description:
The event of the source object which could
be the change event in common but has to be an
{@link qx.event.type.Data} event.

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
targetObject {qx.core.Object} The object which the source should
be bind to.
@param.description:
The object which the source should
be bind to.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: targetProperty {String} The property name of the target object.
@param.description: The property name of the target object.

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
options {Map} A map containing the options. See
{@link #bind} for more information.
@param.description:
A map containing the options. See
{@link #bind} for more information.

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
arrayIndex {String} The index of the given array if its an array
to bind.
@param.description:
The index of the given array if its an array
to bind.

@return.name: @return
@return.body:
{var} Returns the internal id for that binding. This can be used
for referencing the binding or e.g. for removing. This is not an atomic
id so you can't you use it as a hash-map index. It's the id which will
be returned by the {@link qx.core.Object#addListener} method.
@return.description:
Returns the internal id for that binding. This can be used
for referencing the binding or e.g. for removing. This is not an atomic
id so you can't you use it as a hash-map index. It's the id which will
be returned by the {@link qx.core.Object#addListener} method.

@throws.name: @throws
@throws.body:
{qx.core.AssertionError} If the event is no data event or
there is no property definition for the target object and target
property.
@throws.description:
If the event is no data event or
there is no property definition for the target object and target
property.

@description.name: @description
@description.body:
This method takes the given value, checks if the user has given a
converter and converts the value to its target type. If no converter is
given by the user, the {@link #__defaultConversion} will try to convert
the value.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: value {var} The value which possibly should be converted.
@param.description: The value which possibly should be converted.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: targetObject {qx.core.Object} The target object.
@param.description: The target object.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: targetPropertyChain {String} The property name of the target object.
@param.description: The property name of the target object.

@param.name: @param
@param.body:
options {Map} The options map which can includes the converter.
For a detailed information on the map, take a look at
{@link #bind}.
@param.description:
The options map which can includes the converter.
For a detailed information on the map, take a look at
{@link #bind}.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: sourceObject {qx.core.Object} The source object for the binding.
@param.description: The source object for the binding.

@return.name: @return
@return.body:
{var} The converted value. If no conversion has been done, the
value property will be returned.
@return.description:
The converted value. If no conversion has been done, the
value property will be returned.

@throws.name: @throws
@throws.body:
{qx.core.AssertionError} If there is no property definition
of the given target object and target property.
@throws.description:
If there is no property definition
of the given target object and target property.

@return.name: @return

@return.description: The name of the change event.

@throws.body:

the given object property pair.
@throws.description:
If there is no property definition of
the given object property pair.

@description.name: @description
@description.body:
Removes the binding with the given id from the given sourceObject. The
id has to be the id returned by any of the bind functions.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: sourceObject {qx.core.Object} The source object of the binding.
@param.description: The source object of the binding.

@param.name: @param
@param.body: id {var} The id of the binding.
@param.description: The id of the binding.

@throws.name: @throws
@throws.body: {Error} If the binding could not be found.
@throws.description: If the binding could not be found.

@description.name: @description

removed.

@description.name: @description
@description.body: Returns an array which lists all bindings.

@param.name: @param

@return.name: @return
@return.body:
{Array} An array of binding informations. Every binding
information is an array itself containing id, sourceObject,
sourceEvent, targetObject and targetProperty in that order.
@return.description:
An array of binding informations. Every binding
information is an array itself containing id, sourceObject,
sourceEvent, targetObject and targetProperty in that order.

@description.name: @description
@description.body:
Removes all binding in the whole application. After that not a single
binding is left.

@deprecated.name: @deprecated
@deprecated.body:
{6.0} dispose and destructors are deprecated because of automatic memory management; this
will only work for objects explicitly registered with ObjectRegistry.register

@description.name: @description
@description.body:
Returns a map containing for every bound object an array of data binding
information. The key of the map is the hash code of the bound objects.
Every binding is represented by an array containing id, sourceObject,
sourceEvent, targetObject and targetProperty.

@description.name: @description

binding in console. For that it uses {@link qx.log.Logger}.

@param.description: the source of the binding.

@param.name: @param

@param.description: The id of the binding.

@description.name: @description

Debug function which shows all bindings in the log console. To get only
one binding in the console use {@link #showBindingInLog}
